chapter.title: Host Clusters
chapter.para:
The cluster specific elements which may be contained in the cluster description are as follows:
cpu A server CPU reference which defines which CPU type must be supported by all hosts in the cluster. See
data_center A reference to the data center of which this cluster is a member. See
version The compatibility level of the cluster (see )
supported_versions A list of the versions to which the cluster may be updated (see )
For example:
chapter.screen: <cluster id="99408929-82cf-4dc7-a532-9d998063fa95" href="/rhevm-api/clusters/99408929-82cf-4dc7-a532-9d998063fa95"> <name>Default</name> <description>The default server cluster</description> <cpu id="Intel Xeon 45nm Core2"/> <data_center id="d70d5e2d-b8ad-494a-a4d2-c7a5631073c4" href="/rhevm-api/datacenters/d70d5e2d-b8ad-494a-a4d2-c7a5631073c4"/> <version major="2" minor="2"/> <supported_versions> <version major="2" minor="3"/> </supported_versions> <link rel="networks" href="/rhevm-api/clusters/99408929-82cf-4dc7-a532-9d998063fa95/networks"/> </cluster>
chapter.para: When creating a new cluster, the name, cpu id and datacenter id properties are required. Only the name, description and cpu id elements may be updated post-creation.

section.title: Associating Networks With a Cluster
section.para: The collection referenced by link rel="networks" represents the set of networks associated with a given cluster. Every host within the cluster must have a network interface attached to that network in order for the network to be operational.
The network representations are as described in , except they also contain a cluster id reference to the cluster in question.

The networks collection may be manipulated as described in . Associating a network with the cluster is achieved by POSTing a network reference (identifying the network either by its id or name) to the collection. Removing an association is achieved by DELETEing the appropriate element in the collection.
